Well Peter I could very happily watch you
draw all day I will get killed by my producer

6.text:
if I don’t ask some questions so firstly
you played quite a different in Series 9 than

12.text:

15.text:
I think people just wanted to warm him up
a little bit. Given that the process of regeneration

21.text:
is probably quite a bizarre one. You probably
don’t know who you are yourself.

26.text:
And I think as it was a new regeneration cycle
it probably was more of a shock than usual

34.text:
to him. I think he didn’t know who he was.
I actually quite like the slightly darker

41.text:
Doctor who was around in my first season but
the new one, let’s call him the new one,

48.text:
he’s funnier. You know. I’m quite light
hearted myself most of the time so I think

55.text:
to do more gags and have more of a laugh but
it’s trying to keep both of those things

58.text:
alive, that’s the challenge of Doctor Who.
It’s to try and be likable and also rather

67.text:
strange and distant, you know. Because he
is and he should be. He’s not a human being

74.text:
and he should have something of this character
that I’m drawing now in him.

81.text:
When you fire that first shot, no matter how
right you feel, you have no idea who’s going

89.text:
You don’t know who’s children are going
to scream and burn.

92.text: How many hearts will be broken?

99.text:
How much blood will spill until everybody
does what they were always going to do from

103.text: the very beginning. Sit down and talk!

106.text:
Well let’s talk about that speech in The
Zygon Inversion which is not only one of the

111.text:
Doctor’s greatest speeches but it’s also
transcended the show and it’s been shared

116.text: media. I mean, how does this make you feel?

117.text:
I feel very privileged to say that speech.
It was written by Peter Harness and probably

125.text:
Steven had a hand in it as well. They were
great words to say. You never know when you

132.text:
something how it’s going to turn out. But
to have such a vocal attack on the idea of

140.text:
war is so rare, weirdly in our culture now
and it was so right for the Doctor to do it.

152.text:
to do. And funnily enough the day we did it,
the American ambassador was visiting us. Can

157.text:
you believe that the American ambassador comes
to visit and he had a whole entourage

161.text:
of security men and all of that sort of stuff
but when I finished it, the first time I did

169.text:
it, you know it’s about 9 pages long so
remembering it is the hard thing and I’d

179.text:
and do it in one go. But it was very sweet.
The first time I did it there was a round

184.text:
of applause which came from the American ambassador
and all of his people. It’s a wonderful

190.text:
speech and someone asked me to do it again
when we were in New Zealand and we did it

196.text:
for an audience which was very nice. It had
a sort of life, a life beyond the show and

206.text:
course I could do it differently then. That’s
what was nice as well, a change to do it slightly

209.text:
differently from the way we did it on the
programme. They’re great words.

213.text:
Now in my opinion, Heaven Sent is a masterpiece,
it’s certainly one of my favourite episodes

217.text:
from Series 9 but how did you feel when you
were told you would be doing an episode on

222.text:
Well it was odd. People kept saying to me
there’s going to be this episode and you’re

226.text:
just going to be in it on your own and I couldn’t
really figure out what that meant and I thought

231.text:
how could I be in an episode on my own? So
I couldn’t imagine what it was. But I was

238.text:
quite excited about it because I knew Steven
would come up with a wonderful idea but when

245.text:
read it I was just blown away, I thought it
was an amazing story but I also was nervous

250.text:
because I thought you know, it’s just me
and I don’t know how many faces I can pull.

255.text:
So it was challenging. But I knew Rachel was
directing it, Rachel Talalay and she’s brilliant

265.text:
and I knew she had lots of ideas about how
to do it so I knew we were in very safe hands.

272.text:
Jamie who played the Veil is fantastic. He
also played Colony Sarff in the earlier Dalek

280.text:
story. He was lovely to have around but obviously
his hands were full, his clothes were full

289.text:
So as a fan, was it a massive thrill to go
to the Doctor’s home planet Gallifrey and

293.text:
are there any other worlds from Doctor Who
that you’d like to visit?

296.text:
Well Mondas obviously as you know. I’d like
to get to Mondas. Gallifrey was great, yeah.

305.text:
It was a bit more tropical than I had anticipated
it would be. I always thought it looked more

310.text:
like Shepherds Bush, Television Centre in
particular. What other planets? Yeah, I’d

319.text:
like to go to go back to Vortis and see what
our Zarbi and Menoptera would look like if

327.text:
spend the money on them that they didn’t
have back then. Yeah, I’d like to do that.

333.text:
And Axos, I’d like to go to Axos and see
how the Axons are getting on.

342.text:
Plenty of places to go. Lots of new places
to go too. And nice to go to Earth at various

349.text:
different times. I’d like to go and see
the moon landing from the moon.

355.text:
To be hiding behind a rock there and watch
that all going on with them not realising

360.text:
that they were being watched. Perhaps that’s
what happened. That’s an episode right there.

365.text:
Well obviously this series saw the departure
of Jenna Coleman’s Clara. Have you recovered

370.text:
from this emotional exit and what are your
hopes for the new companion?

373.text:
Yeah, no it was really sad. It was very sad
to say goodbye to Jenna. I didn’t want her

378.text:
to go. She looked after me so well. We have
a great working relationship. She’s a brilliant

385.text:
and wonderful friend. Just great to have around.
I sort of don’t really… I haven’t done

392.text:
a series without her so I sort of really don’t
quite believe she won’t be there when we

399.text:
back. But she won’t be. There will be a
new person in it. That’s going to be very

402.text:
exciting because it’s a wonderful part which
I know about. The person is going to be very

411.text:
and I think everybody is going to really enjoy
it. But it’s going to be a whole different

417.text:
tone. In a way it’s going to be like discovering
Doctor Who all over again which is nice which

427.text:
what happens to Doctor with people. But no,
Jenna – I’m thrilled that she’s doing

432.text:
so well and you know, she’s a brilliant
actress. She’s going to do so much brilliant

443.text:
And maybe we’ll see her again. Maybe the
Doctor will see her again. I don’t know.

445.text:
Well The Husbands of River Song is a straight
up comedy piece and on the show we loved seeing

450.text:
the Doctor react to the interior of the TARDIS
and also seeing the Doctor laugh

454.text:
because it’s also something we’ve not
seen very much of. Did you enjoy the change

458.text:
of tone and will we see more of this in Series
10?

462.text:
Yeah, I did. It’s interesting as we go into
the past here and look at these older Doctors

470.text:
to see how so many of them were you know…
Patrick Troughton is the impish warm one.

482.text:
Tom Baker will revisit some of that. But both
Jon Pertwee and William Hartnell had a kind

488.text:
of severity about them which I think is quite
fitting to the role and it’s trying get

494.text:
things to coexist I guess. So yeah, I like
when we have a laugh. I like when we have

503.text:
gags but I don’t like when the Doctor is
simply a clown. Tom Baker was never just a

511.text:
he had an enormous kind of range – whoops,
my pencil is breaking – he had an normous

518.text:
range of expressions which could also communicate
a kind of weird alien-ness.

526.text:
So you know, you’ve got to be likable so
I guess maybe we were trying to make the Doctor

534.text: likable. I always find him likable.
